entry.title: IFRS 18 Compliance for Treasury and Risk Management in SAP Cloud ERP: Key Impacts and Approaches
entry.content:
Purpose of this blog

IFRS 18 becomes effective on 1 January 2027. This blog is tailored to two key audience groups using Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) mainly in SAP Cloud ERP (aka S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition; hereinafter referred to as Public Cloud).

  1. Corporate treasurers and treasury accountants responsible for presenting treasury-related profit or loss in compliance with IFRS 18;
  2. FI/CO, TRM configuration experts, as well as implementation partners who are responsible for implementation or maintenance projects to align the systems with IFRS 18 requirements.

The primary goal of this blog is to deliver clear, practical guidance that can be applied now so that TRM-generated profit or loss postings are classified and presented correctly as Operating, Investing, or Financing categories in the statement of profit or loss, as mandated by IFRS 18.

What you will learn and be able to do

  • Understand the key IFRS 18 changes relevant to TRM and the criticality of categorization of profit or loss based on business purpose and economic substance.
  • Classify TRM profit or loss postings into Operating, Investing, or Financing, including income and expenses from debt and investments, as well as derivative financial instruments where the hedging outcomes align with the categories of the underlying risk exposures.
  • Choose a realization approach in SAP TRM:
    • Approach 1: utilize granular G/L accounts that carry both the “nature” of the profit or loss and its IFRS 18 category.
    • Approach 2: leverage functional areas to carry the IFRS 18 categories on postings while retaining existing “nature-based” profit or loss accounts structure (the recommended approach in most cases).
  • Self-configure your system: for example, derive category-representative Account Assignment References (AARs), set up account determination, and ensure category-representative accounts or functional areas are populated at the time of posting. Configuration details will vary depending on the selected realization approach.
  • Plan the project and timeline: decide your realization approach, complete configuration, perform end-to-end testing, and execute system cutover prior to the first posting period of 2027 or your TRM go-live date—whichever occurs first.
  • Convert outstanding TRM positions: use the app TPM28 to transfer AARs for open OTC transactions or security positions, ensuring future postings reflect the appropriate IFRS 18 categories and operationalizing comparative-period restatement where needed.
  • Embed consistent IFRS 18 categorization across the end-to-end hedge management processes for FX risk—from hedging area definition (with additional differentiation criteria like portfolio) and exposure creation, to the ultimate reflection of categories in the posting journals generated from the FX derivatives or exposure subitems (if hedge accounting is implemented).

Scope and applicability

  • SAP plans to update the Central Business Configuration (CBC) best practice reference content in Public Cloud release 2608 (subject to change) to simplify IFRS 18 implementation for TRM. If you use CBC and your TRM configuration is closely aligned with SAP reference content, you will be able to adopt additional scope item(s) plus limited fine tunings; otherwise, you can follow the self-configuration guidance outlined in this blog. Please note that CBC reference content is exclusively available for Public Cloud.
  • Except for the CBC reference content, all recommendations in this blog can be implemented as of now in both SAP Cloud EPR and SAP Cloud ERP Private (aka S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition; hereinafter referred to as Private Cloud), utilizing standard TRM capabilities. Please note that self-configuration guidance provided in this blog is described in the context of Public Cloud; however, you can still refer to these instructions and utilize the equivalent IMG activities or functions in Private Cloud.
  • The blog focuses solely on IFRS 18’s presentation requirements for TRM-generated profit or loss. Provisions of IFRS 9 Financial Instruments—such as classification and measurement of financial instruments, hedge accounting—remain unaffected and are not addressed or modified in this content.

By following the guidance provided, you will be able to:

  • Establish a repeatable way for classifying TRM-related profit or loss into Operating, Investing, or Financing categories.
  • Ensure that categorization is consistently carried through hedge management processes for FX risk.
  • Be well prepared to present TRM-related financial performance in alignment with IFRS 18 required categories and subtotals in the new format of statement of profit or loss, from the first reporting period beginning on or after 1 January 2027, or earlier if you elect to early-adopt IFRS 18 prior to its effective date.

 

IFRS 18 at a glance

The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) issued IFRS 18 Presentation and Disclosure in Financial Statements in April 2024. IFRS 18 replaces IAS 1 Presentation of Financial Statements. Requirements in IAS 1 that are unchanged have been transferred to IFRS 18 and other Standards. IFRS 18 is effective from 1 January 2027, and companies are permitted to apply IFRS 18 before that date.

IFRS 18 aims to improve how companies communicate in their financial statements, with a focus on information about financial performance in the statement of profit or loss. IFRS 18 will affect all companies in all industries. Although IFRS 18 will not affect how companies measure financial performance, it will affect how companies present and disclose financial performance.

The main changes introduced by IFRS 18 include, but are not limited to:

  • In the statement of profit or loss—report two new defined subtotals including operating profit, based on a new set of requirements for classifying income and expenses in categories. The newly introduced categories are Operating, Investing and Financing.
  • In the notes—disclose information about some performance measures defined by management, which IFRS 18 identify as ‘management-defined performance measures’ (MPMs).
  • In both the primary financial statements and the notes— requirements for aggregation and disaggregation of information.

 

Impact on Treasury and Risk Management

Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) in Public Cloud generates a wide range of profit or loss postings from:

  • Investing and borrowing via OTC debt instruments (also referred to as money market instruments).
  • Investments in securities (e.g., equities, bonds, ABS/MBS, investment funds)
  • Securities issuances (e.g., bonds, ABS/MBS)
  • Foreign exchange (e.g., FX spot, FX forward, NDF, FX swap)
  • OTC derivatives (e.g., interest rate swap, cross-currency interest rate swap, swaption, FX option, collar, securities option)
  • Trade finance (e.g., bank guarantee, letter of credit)

Under IFRS 18, these postings must be classified into Operating, Investing, or Financing to meet the new subtotals and categorization requirements. The categorization does not alter measurement rules under IFRS 9 but impacts how the TRM-related financial performance is presented in financial statements.

Key ways IFRS 18 affects corporate treasury

Principles: IFRS 18 categorization depends on the business purpose and economic substance (rather than merely the instrument type) and spans the entire lifecycle of financial instruments.

Investing category

The investing category comprises the income and expenses from TRM-managed financial assets or derivatives:

  • Cash equivalents, e.g., investment income and fair value gain or loss from purchased money market funds.
  • Investments in associates, joint ventures and unconsolidated subsidiaries, e.g., dividend income from equity investments.
  • Other assets that generate a return individually and largely independently of the company’s other resources, e.g., interest revenue from investments in interest-bearing instruments like deposits, CDs, bonds, ABS/MBS; fair value gain or loss from marketable securities measured at fair value; realized gain or loss on disposal or derecognition of relevant assets.
  • Derivatives categorized in investing (see details from “Categorization for derivatives”).

Income and expenses classified in the investing category comprises income generated by the assets, income and expenses that arise from the initial and subsequent measurement of the assets, including on derecognition of the assets, and incremental expenses directly attributable to the acquisition and disposal of the assets, for example transaction costs and costs to sell the assets (e.g., fees, commissions, brokerages that are either directly recognized in profit or loss, or capitalized and amortized subsequently).

Financing category

For TRM, the financing category comprises income and expenses that arise from the initial and subsequent measurement of the liabilities that involve the raising of finance (e.g., interest expenses from bonds, loans), including on derecognition of such liabilities (e.g., realized gain or loss on derecognition), and incremental expenses directly attributable to the issue and extinguishment of these liabilities (e.g., fees, commissions, issuance costs of securities such as bonds, either directly recognized in profit or loss, or capitalized and amortized subsequently).

Financing category is also applied to gain or loss from derivatives (see details from “Categorization for derivatives”).

Operating category

The operating category comprises the income and expenses arising from a company’s operation; for TRM, it relates to:

  • Trade finance instruments, e.g., fees, charges, and foreign exchange gain or loss from bank guarantee, letter of credit​.
  • Derivatives categorized in operating (see details from “Categorization for derivatives”).
  • Foreign exchange gain or loss from other TRM-managed monetary items categorized in operating, when the reliefs for undue cost or effort are applied.

Categorization for derivatives

IFRS 18 requires that all gains and losses on a derivative financial instrument used to manage identified risks shall be classified in the same category as the income and expenses affected by the risks being managed. Therefore, derivatives relate to three categories.

  • Investing category: gain or loss from the derivatives that are used to hedge the risks arising from the invested assets categorized in investing as well. Examples:
    • FX derivatives used to hedge the FX risk from the investments in foreign-currency bonds.
    • Interest rate swaps used to hedge the interest rate risk from the investments in variable-rate debt instruments.
    • Securities options used to hedge the stock price risk from the stock investments.
  • Financing category: gain or loss from the derivatives that are used to hedge the risks arising from the financing liabilities categorized in financing as well. Examples:
    • FX derivatives used to hedge the FX risk from the issued foreign-currency bonds.
    • Interest rate swaps used to hedge the interest rate risk from the borrowings or issuances in variable-rate debt instruments.
  • Operating category: gain or loss from the derivatives that are used to hedge the risks arising from the company’s main business activities categorized in operating as well. Example:
    • FX derivatives used to hedge the FX risk from the highly probable forecast transactions related to the company’s main business activities (purchases / sales of goods or services).

For a designated hedging instrument in hedge accounting, the gain or loss arising from the undesignated component shall be classified in the same category as those arising from the designated component. Similarly, the gain or loss of the ineffective portion shall be classified in the same category as the effective portion.

Exceptions:

  • Gain or loss on derivatives (designated as hedging instrument of hedge accounting) is categorized in operating, when the condition of grossing up of gains and losses is met.
  • Gain or loss on derivatives (not designated as hedging instrument of hedge accounting) is categorized in operating, when condition of the grossing up of gains and losses or reliefs for undue cost or effort is met.

The determination logic is illustrated in the following chart.

IFRS 18 B75 provides an example in which grossing up of gains or losses on a FX derivative might arise, for which please check section “Classifying all gains and losses on FX derivative in the operating category”.

Summary

The following mapping matrix outlines, at a detailed level, the potential relationships between profit or loss related line-item elements (or extension line-item elements, classified in IFRS 18 categories) and TRM product categories/product types (as covered in the current scope of Public Cloud).

The above matrix also reveals that the income and expenses arising from TRM may fall into any of the three categories required by IFRS 18—Operating, Investing, or Financing—depending on the economic nature of the financial instrument and the business purpose for which the entity holds or uses it.

When preparing the statement of profit or loss applying IAS 1, usually it is sufficient that the TRM-generated posting journals only reflect the “nature” of the income or expenses, for example, the G/L account “fair value gain or loss” might be sufficient for recognizing the gains or losses arising from the fair value changes on financial assets (or liabilities when applicable) which are evaluated at “fair value through profit or loss (FVTPL)” under IFRS 9. However, when preparing the statement of profit or loss applying IFRS 18, a single G/L account "fair value gains or losses" is insufficiently granular, as it fails to reflect which category—or, to use a more direct term, the "function"—for classifying such income or expenses into Operating, Investing, or Financing.

Companies with specified main business activities

Above discussion is based on the corporate treasury, which means the company’s main business activities do not include investing in assets or providing financing to customers (in the terminology of IFRS 18: specified main business activities).

For the companies with specified main business activities, the categorization may differ significantly. For example, some companies invest in assets as a main business activity (e.g., investment entities, investment property companies, insurers), such companies classify in the operating category the income and expenses that arise from those assets that would otherwise be classified in the investing category.

This blog focuses on corporate treasury (companies without specified main business activities).

 

Realization approaches

To achieve fine-grained detail within TRM-generated profit or loss posting journals while also reflecting the categories (Operating, Investing, or Financing), basically two approaches are available.

Approach 1: Via granular G/L accounts

This approach is based on creating category-representative profit or loss accounts, where each account maps unambiguously to one IFRS 18 category (or “function”) in addition to a single “nature”. This means profit or loss accounts should be replicated relative to those required under IAS 1.

As the key dimension for G/L account determination in TRM, Account Assignment References (AARs) must also be replicated per IFRS 18 category. The TRM account determination configuration should then be adapted: profit or loss-relevant account symbols should point to the new category-representative accounts via these newly introduced category-aligned AARs, so that the right profit or loss account is picked at the time of posting. The AARs should include the category in their IDs and descriptions, and be derived from the attributes of transactions or security positions (product category, product type, transaction category, transaction type, valuation class, portfolio, hedging classification, etc.). More details regarding configuration and effects of this approach will be elaborated in the section “self-configuration”.

Pros

  • Simplified journal generation: the IFRS 18 category is inherently embedded in the G/L account, eliminating the need for additional fields to capture categories in posting journals.
  • Ledger-specific flexibility: account determination can be varied by accounting principle (valuation area) if multiple reporting requirements apply.
  • Minimal downstream dependency: reduces the need for reporting or consolidation tools to adopt new dimensions for IFRS 18 categories, as segregation is already enabled at the account level.

Cons

  • Chart-of-accounts proliferation: results in a significant increase in profit or loss accounts ( “triplicated” for the three core IFRS 18 categories, or even more due to deeper breakdown requirements), with further expansion if additional dimensions are added (e.g., counterparty relationship).
  • Limited adaptability: makes it harder to adjust classifications as accounting standards evolve or business needs change, due to the tight coupling of categories to static G/L account master data.
  • Maintenance overhead: increases the burden of maintaining G/L account master data and TRM account determination configurations.
  • Higher risk of incorrect postings: introduces relatively greater risk, because posting errors can only be detected post-posting without pre-posting validation (note that some apps don’t support test run), or users can manually select accounts outside of automated TRM posting processes.

Use when

  • The TRM scope is limited and the usage of treasury instruments is stable (minimizing the need for frequent G/L account master data and configuration adjustments).
  • The reporting or consolidation tools mandate IFRS 18 category separation at G/L account level.
  • The functional areas in SAP are already heavily reserved for cost of sales accounting or other statutory purposes, therefore, functional areas cannot be repurposed for TRM-related IFRS 18 categorization. While technically feasible, this approach would likely offer little to no benefit compared with replicating G/L accounts.
  • Other modules adopt a consistent IFRS 18 realization approach—also utilizing granular G/L accounts (refer to central SAP note 3694359 for further details).

Approach 2: Via functional areas (recommended approach)

In this approach, the existing TRM profit and loss accounts (designed for IAS 1 presentation purpose) remain unchanged, these accounts focus solely on their “nature” and not additionally on the IFRS 18 category. This approach eliminates the need to create new G/L accounts. The IFRS 18 categories are instead captured by means of the Functional Areas, which are obtained from TRM transactions or security positions and passed on to TRM-generated posting journals to reflect the category: Operating, Investing, or Financing.

Under this approach, it is required to create three new functional areas for Operating, Investing, and Financing (or more if deeper breakdown is needed). Same as Approach 1, creating new AARs and defining derivation for new AARs from the attributes of TRM transactions or security positions remain necessary configurations. Through the mapping of the functional areas to new AARs (at company code level), the functional area is populated in the Position Indicator and then propagated to the Universal Journal at the time of posting. The functional area from TRM takes precedence over that derived from G/L account master data or account assignments (e.g., cost center, WBS element). More details regarding configuration and effects of this approach will be elaborated in the section “self-configuration”.

Pros

  • No chart of accounts proliferation: eliminates the need for new G/L accounts, minimizing disruption to existing “nature-based” account structure.
  • Higher agility: categories can be updated centrally by AAR-to-Functional area mapping, without modifying static G/L account master data.
  • Flexible configuration: the AAR-to-Functional area mapping is a “current setting” configuration, which can be directly done in test and production tenants without transporting configuration.
  • Pre-posting category visibility: the category-representative functional area is embedded in the position indicator of transaction or security position before posting occurs—enabling proactive visibility into which IFRS 18 category the resulting profit or loss will fall into, rather than requiring retrospective verification after posting is complete or via test run of posting.
  • Supports parallel accounting: the same original business transaction can be presented differently across ledgers (valuation areas) without requiring separate accounts, since AAR derivation can be valuation area-specific, which in turn means that functional area determination can also be valuation area-specific.

Cons

  • Functional area usage: requires that functional area is available for external profit or loss presentation and not already in use for a conflicting purpose,  for example, functional areas are already heavily reserved for cost of sales accounting or other statutory purposes, therefore, functional areas cannot be repurposed for TRM-related IFRS 18 categorization. While technically feasible, this approach would likely offer little to no benefit compared with replicating G/L accounts.
  • Reporting dependency: reporting and consolidation tools must consistently include functional areas to produce IFRS 18 categories and subtotals.
  • Higher configuration overhead: adds an extra AAR-to-Functional area mapping (vs. Approach 1’s direct AAR-to-G/L account mapping), requiring additional configuration and stricter governance over cross-validation of AAR derivations and AAR-to-Functional area mappings to ensure accurate IFRS 18 categorization.

Use when

  • Minimization of G/L account master data maintenance and retention of “nature-based” profit or loss accounts is a priority.
  • Leverage of SAP-delivered CBC best practice content is planned for TRM and IFRS 18 implementation in Public Cloud.
  • The functional area capability (although it was initially introduced for cost of sales accounting) can be re-purposed to fulfill the IFRS 18 categorization for TRM.
  • Other modules adopt a consistent IFRS 18 realization approach—also utilizing functional areas (refer to central SAP note 3694359 for further details).

 

Implementation advice

Self-configuration

This section details core configuration considerations for self-configuration of either Approach 1 or Approach 2.

Note: Described in the context of Public Cloud, this guidance also applies to Private Cloud—simply reference the instructions and leverage equivalent IMG activities or functional counterparts in Private Cloud.

Approach 1: Via granular G/L accounts

To manually implement Approach 1, first, please create additional fine-grained profit or loss accounts in General Ledger Accounting.

A critical subsequent consideration is how to determine the appropriate G/L account from the TRM module. As a key dimension for G/L account determination in TRM, Account Assignment References (AARs) shall be configured such that IFRS 18 categories (operating, investing, financing) are encoded in their IDs and names. This means AARs will need to be at least “triplicated” relative to those required for IAS 1-compliant requirements. AARs are created through configuration activity 102099 Define Account Assignment References.

The next critical configuration step is to derive AARs for OTC transactions (money market, foreign exchange, derivatives, trade finance), security positions (stock, investment fund, bond, ABS/MBS, shareholding) or exposure subitems (if hedge accounting for net open exposures is in scope). To accomplish this, please configure substitution rules for AAR derivation based on pre-conditions including (but not limited to) product category, product type, transaction category, transaction type, valuation class, portfolio, and hedging classification, etc. For guidance on using the relevant substitution tools, refer to the help documentations:

  • Account Assignment References - OTC Transactions (Substitution Rules)
  • Account Assignment References - Securities (Substitution Rules)
  • Account Assignment References - Exposure Subitems (Substitution Rules)

The following table outlines potential pre-conditions for deriving AARs across different TRM product categories or product types:

As the last key configuration step, please assign the new profit or loss G/L accounts (and existing balance sheet accounts) to existing account symbols and new AARs via configuration activity 103014 Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management.

The picture below shows a configuration example in which gains or losses from FX forward contracts are classified into three categories—achieved via granular G/L accounts.

Approach 2: Via functional areas

Approach 2 eliminates the need for additional G/L accounts. However, IFRS 18 presentation category granularity must still be embedded in new AARs, as the derivation of functional areas is dependent on the AARs. Additionally, substitution rules for new AARs derivation and the configuration for assignment of existing G/L accounts to account symbols and new AARs remain necessary.

The following configuration steps must be considered under Approach 2:

  1. Replicate AARs per IFRS 18 category
    1. Define Account Assignment References (AARs) that embed the category in the IDs and descriptions (effectively triplicating the AAR set used under IAS 1).
    2. Configuration activity: 102099 Define Account Assignment References.
  2. Derive AARs via substitution rules
    1. Create substitution rules that derive the correct category-representative AARs based on pre-conditions such as product category, product type, transaction category, transaction type, valuation class, portfolio, and hedging classification.
    2. Refer to the following help documentations for the substitution tools:
      1. Account Assignment References - OTC Transactions (Substitution Rules)
      2. Account Assignment References - Securities (Substitution Rules)
      3. Account Assignment References - Exposure Subitems (Substitution Rules)
  3. Define new functional areas
    1. Create new functional areas representing the IFRS 18 categories (Operating, Investing, Financing).
    2. Configuration activity: 102363 Define Functional Area.
  4. Assign the new functional areas
    1. Assign the new functional areas to company codes and new AARs.
    2. Configuration activity: 105341 Allocate Additional Account Assignments to Account Assignment References.
  5. Determine G/L accounts
    1. Assign the existing “nature-based” profit or loss accounts (and balance sheet accounts) to the existing account symbols and the newly introduced AARs.
    2. Configuration activity: 103014 Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management.

The picture below shows a configuration example in which FX forward contracts are classified into three categories—achieved via functional areas.

Once these configurations are completed, the functional area will be populated in the Position Indicator of newly created OTC transactions and security positions.

The three pictures below illustrate how three FX forward contracts are assigned with different category-representative functional areas by specifying different hedging classifications (in alignment with the preceding configuration example).

Subsequently, the functional area in the Position Indicator is propagated to the corresponding posting journals generated from TRM transactions and security positions. Moreover, the functional area supplied by the TRM position indicator (as the calling application) takes precedence over that derived from G/L account master data or account assignment (e.g., cost center, WBS element), if applicable. For further details, please refer to SAP help documentation: Deriving Functional Areas.

There is an alternative for Approach 2:

  • Configuration activity 105341 Allocate Additional Account Assignments to Account Assignment References: assign category-representative cost centers to company codes and AARs; and then functional areas of cost centers will be used for postings.
  • Do not maintain functional areas for profit or loss accounts—these overrule the functional areas derived from cost centers.

SAP best practice content

SAP plans to ship additional TRM best practice reference content through new scope item(s) in release 2608 of Public Cloud, available for Central Business Configuration (CBC) exclusively. The reference content is planned to be in alignment with Approach 2 and include:

  • Predefined functional areas for Operating, Investing, and Financing.
  • New Account Assignment References (AARs) that carry IFRS 18 categorization.
  • Account determination entries that map existing G/L accounts to those new AARs and existing account symbols.

Activating the new scope item(s) via scope extension will deploy the reference configuration; limited manual fine-tuning is anticipated. The new scope item(s) is designed to accelerate IFRS 18-aligned TRM setups for customers who are eligible to leverage it (see the section below).

Any news regarding the delivery of best practice content will be posted on this blog—please stay tuned. Please also note that this best practice content delivery plan is subject to change.

Self-configuration or SAP best practice content?

Use the criteria below to decide whether to configure IFRS 18-related TRM settings yourself or adopt SAP-delivered scope item(s). The key determinants are how the configuration in the system is administered (CBC versus Manage Your Solution), the extent of TRM customization already in place, and your project timing relative to the planned scope item release (target August 2026, subject to change).

Choose self-configuration if any of the following applies:

  • The configuration activities in Public Cloud are accessed via app Manage Your Solution rather than Central Business Configuration (CBC) Project Experience or app Implementation Activities (for 3SL systems).
  • TRM is already in production and the configurations are heavily customized (for example, bespoke AARs, G/L accounts, and account determination). In this case, IFRS 18 changes will also need custom work, and reference content will add limited value.
  • It is required to begin implementing IFRS 18 for TRM before the planned scope item release in August 2026 (subject to change), for example to be early adopter of IFRS 18 in 2026.

Leverage SAP Best Practice content (CBC-managed scope item(s)) if any of the following applies:

  • TRM is already in production and predominantly based on SAP TRM reference content (for example, the AARs, G/L accounts, and account determination are consistent with or closely aligned to the reference content). In this scenario, the TRM IFRS 18 scope item(s) plus light fine-tuning should meet requirements.
  • The TRM implementation (including non-IFRS 18 settings) has not started by the time the scope item(s) is released.
  • The TRM implementation is in progress but not yet live when the scope item(s) is released, with an intended reliance on SAP reference content predominantly.

 

Considerations for the implementation project timeline

IFRS 18 is effective from 1 January 2027. Financial statements for annual reporting periods beginning on or after that date must be prepared in accordance with IFRS 18.

It is recommended to complete all TRM-related tasks before the first posting period of 2027 (if TRM is already in production by end of 2026) or before the TRM go-live (if TRM goes live in 2027 or later), at a minimum:

  • Decide the categorization approach. Confirm whether you will implement Approach 1 (via granular G/L accounts), Approach 2 (via functional areas), or a qualified alternative suited to your landscape and reporting needs.
  • Configure the system. Either perform self-configuration or, if applicable, activate the IFRS 18-related TRM scope item(s) and fine-tune the reference content to meet your requirements.
  • Perform end-to-end tests. Validate TRM processes and posting results in the test tenant, including categorization (Operating, Investing, or Financing), numbers of categories and subtotals in reporting, and any parallel ledger views required.
  • Cut over to production. Import the validated configuration—include self-configuration and CBC deployment (if applicable) customizing transport requests—into the production tenant. If needed, run the Transfer Account Assignment Reference for outstanding positions; see “Conversion for outstanding transactions and security positions” for details.

The TRM implementation may be part of a broader IFRS 18 program or an ERP project. How TRM-generated profit or loss journals are incorporated into individual (and consolidated, if applicable) profit or loss statements is also essential, even though this topic is not elaborated on herein.

 

Conversion for outstanding transactions and security positions

If TRM is in production before the IFRS 18 transition date (for most companies, 1 January 2027), all open treasury transactions and security positions should be “converted” so that any future postings generated from them will carry the correct IFRS 18 categories. This “conversion” aligns the Account Assignment References (and functional areas, if Approach 2 is selected) on existing positions with new IFRS 18 setup.

Recommended tool: Transfer Account Assignment Reference (App ID: TPM28).

What TPM28 does:

  • Transfers legacy AARs to the new IFRS 18-compliant AARs on the Position Indicator for each affected transaction and security position.
  • By default, posts a book value position transfer from the legacy AAR to the new AAR:
    • Clears the book value using the position account derived from the legacy AAR.
    • Re-recognizes the same book value using the position account derived from the new AAR.

When to suppress position-transfer postings: for most IFRS 18 “conversions”, the position accounts remain unchanged. In those cases, the position-transfer postings are operationally unnecessary. To avoid them, set the relevant update types as non-posting-relevant before running TPM28.

Additional effects if Approach 2 (via functional areas) is implemented:

  • When TPM28 transfers the AAR, the functional area derived for the new AAR via configuration activity 105341 (Allocate Additional Account Assignments to Account Assignment References) is also written into the Position Indicator and associated with the row of new AAR.
  • Subsequent postings from those positions will then carry the functional area in the Universal Journal. The functional area supplied by TRM position indicator takes precedence over derivations from G/L master data or account assignments.

TPM28 also provides the indicator “Transfer of P&L Postings” to “reclassify” current-year profit or loss. If this indicator is selected, additional effects of TPM28 will be:

  • All relevant profit or loss postings from the legacy AAR for the current fiscal year up to the TPM28 key date are cleared and re-posted with the new AAR.
    • With Approach 1: the re-posted journals will use the new category-representative profit or loss accounts.
    • With Approach 2: the re-posted journals will include the new functional areas.
  • To ensure all profit or loss are transferred, make sure all relevant account symbols are configured in configuration activity 104458 Assign Update Types for Account Assignment Reference Transfer.

Using “Transfer of P&L Postings” of TPM28 can fulfill restatement of profit or loss for comparative period (typically fiscal year 2026) asked by IFRS 18. To achieve this, TPM28 with “Transfer of P&L Postings” selected should be executed at the end of 2026, so the re-postings with new categories are recorded in fiscal year 2026—the profit or loss are “restated” for 2026.

Note: IFRS 18 prescribes restatement at the statement level; TPM28 performs re-postings at journal level which are then reflected at the statement level.

The picture below illustrates TPM28’s effects on position indicator and postings for a FX forward contract categorized as Investing.

Practical guidance:

  • Run TPM28 first in a test tenant and reconcile pre- and post-runs by verifying the cleared and re-posted amounts in the dimension such as G/L accounts, functional areas, etc., for OTC transactions and security positions. If applicable, use the reporting tool to check the restated profit or loss as well.
  • Choose a dedicated key date (for example, end of fiscal year 2026) for running TPM28 in production tenant, communicate a conversion window and ensure that:
    • Any changes to transactions or security positions up to the key date have been completed.
    • All profit or loss related to the open positions up to the key date have been recognized (fix and post flows, valuation, accrual, etc.), if “restated” should be performed.
    • Avoid creating or changing transactions or security positions during execution of TPM28 and before completion of post-run verification.
    • The posting period of the key date is open.
    • Prior to the production run of TPM28 in production tenant, perform test run first, and check the results of test run mode.

For further details, please refer to the SAP Help documentation: Transfer Account Assignment Reference.

 

IFRS 18 categorization throughout the E2E hedge management process

Appropriate categorization of profit or loss is a fundamental requirement for applying IFRS 18 within TRM, prior discussions focused on financial instruments: their categorization dictates that of associated profit or loss. For hedge management processes, categorization logic can extend upstream to the mitigated risks, enabling consistent end-to-end application.

Hedge management of net open exposures (FX risk)

Within the Hedge Management of Net Open Exposures (FX Risk) functionality, the Hedge Management Cockpit serves as the central tool, providing a consolidated overview of FX exposures and the corresponding FX derivatives used to mitigate FX risk within a defined hedging area.

The exposures managed by the Hedge Management Cockpit usually arise from variability in cash flows that is attributable to FX risks associated with highly probable forecast transactions, unrecognized firm commitments, or recognized assets or liabilities.

To incorporate IFRS 18 categories into this E2E net open exposure hedging process, the setup of Hedging Areas (the process starting point) must include differentiation criteria—such as the portfolio (a dedicated differentiation to capture the IFRS 18 category is not available, yet)—to represent IFRS 18 categories for both exposures and hedges.

Accordingly, when the FX exposures are created, the IFRS 18 category-representative portfolios must be explicitly specified in the exposures to differentiate exposure categories. This portfolio will then propagate throughout the entire process, including:

  • Snapshots of exposures
  • Hedge requests
  • Trade requests (if Trading Platform Integration is enabled)
  • Ultimately, the FX derivatives themselves (e.g., FX forwards, FX options)

The substitution rules can be configured using the portfolio as a pre-condition, enabling the derivation of category-representative Account Assignment References (AARs) for the FX derivatives. Subsequently, all posting journals generated from these FX derivatives will be IFRS 18-compliant—regardless of whether the above described Approach 1 (via granular G/L accounts) or Approach 2 (via functional areas) is implemented.

Hedge management of balance sheet FX risk

The Hedge Management of Balance Sheet FX Risk functionality is designed to capture the FX exposures arising from the changes in fair value of recognized assets or liabilities that are attributable to FX risk, and the FX exposures will be subsequently mitigated through corresponding FX derivatives.

To incorporate IFRS 18 categories into this end-to-end balance sheet FX risk hedge management process, balance sheet FX exposures must include category-related information at the process outset. To achieve this, it is recommended to create distinct category-representative Key Figure Groups, which can be differentiated based on criteria such as G/L accounts.

Subsequent steps include:

  • Generating snapshots based on these distinct Key Figure Groups—these snapshots will also be segregated by the IFRS 18 categories.
  • Creating hedge requests separately from each snapshot. During this step, explicitly assign the corresponding category-representative portfolio to each snapshot, ensuring hedge requests are segregated by the IFRS 18 categories via the portfolio dimension.
  • If Trading Platform Integration is enabled, trade requests will inherit the portfolio from the corresponding hedge requests.
  • Ultimately, the FX derivatives (e.g., FX forwards, FX options) will contain the category-representative portfolios.

Like the Hedge Management of Net Open Exposures process, the substitution rules can be configured using the portfolio as a pre-condition to derive category-representative AARs for the FX derivatives. Posting journals generated from these FX derivatives will then be IFRS 18-compliant—regardless of whether Approach 1 (via granular G/L accounts) or Approach 2 (via functional areas) is implemented.

Classifying all gains and losses on FX derivative in the operating category

As described in “Impact on Treasury and Risk Management”, the default requirement of IFRS 18 is that all gains and losses on a derivative used to manage identified risks shall be classified in the same category as the income and expenses affected by the risks being managed. This basic principle is also reflected in all previously described examples relevant to FX derivatives.

However, if applying this basic principle would lead to the grossing up of gains and losses, all gains and losses on the derivative shall instead be classified in the operating category. Additionally, for a derivative that is not designated as a hedging instrument under IFRS 9 hedge accounting but is used to manage identified risks, if classifying its gains and losses into specific categories would involve undue cost or effort, all such gains and losses on the derivative shall likewise be classified in the operating category.

IFRS 18 states that grossing up of gains and losses might arise from situations in which:

  1. an entity uses financial instruments to manage the risks of a group of items with offsetting risk positions; and
  2. the risks managed affect line items in more than one category of the statement of profit or loss.

IFRS 18 B75 provides an example in which grossing up of gains or losses on a FX derivative might arise: an entity may use a derivative to manage both the net foreign currency risk on revenue (classified in the operating category) and interest expenses (classified in the financing category). In such cases, the foreign exchange differences on the revenue are offset by the foreign exchange differences on the interest expenses and the gains or losses on the derivative. However, the entity classifies the foreign exchange differences on the revenue in a different category from the foreign exchange differences on the interest expenses. To present the gain or loss on the derivative in each category, an entity would need to present in each category a larger gain or loss than occurred on the derivative. Applying the requirements in paragraphs B70–B73 of IFRS 18, an entity shall not gross up the gains or losses in this manner and instead shall classify any gain or loss on the derivative in the operating category.

These provisions under IFRS 18 establish a “practical exception”—meaning that the approach described in the sections Hedge management of net open exposures (FX risk) and Hedge management of balance sheet FX risk (where categories are segmented at the exposure level first and passed through the E2E process) may not be required in certain scenarios. Specifically, when conditions for grossing up of gains and losses or undue cost or effort are met, it is permissible to classify all gains and losses from FX derivatives in the operating category instead of segmenting them across multiple categories. For confirmation on the applicability of this treatment in practice, please consult your auditors in detail.

 

Appendix

Additional Account Assignment Derivation

Additional account assignment derivation may also be required to meet IFRS 18 requirements in certain cases.

One example of intercompany loan is currently under review by the IFRS Interpretations Committee (Committee):

  • In individual financial statements, the borrowing entity classifies relevant income or expenses (including interest expenses, foreign exchange gain or loss) in the financing category, while the lending entity classifies relevant income or expenses (including interest revenue, foreign exchange gain or loss) in the investing category.
  • However, the foreign exchange gain or loss from the individual financial statements of the two entities cannot be fully eliminated during consolidation, as the two entities adopt different functional currencies.
  • When preparing consolidated financial statements, the group may recognize such foreign exchange gain or loss within the operating category, according to the tentative agenda decision published by the Committee.

In this example, a single categorization dimension (whether embedded in the G/L account or functional area) plus the trading partner in the Universal Journal may be insufficient. This is because the categories differ between individual and consolidated financial statements, and such intercompany loan transactions should be separated from other intercompany transactions that may not require this discrepant treatment of foreign exchange difference in consolidated financial statement. Therefore, an additional dimension can be introduced—for example, a dedicated financial transaction type (RMVCT)—to denote the foreign currency valuation results for intercompany loans, enabling the corresponding categorization of related foreign exchange gain and loss in:

  • Individual financial statements:
    • Approach 1:
      • Account “Foreign exchange gain or loss, investing” → Investing category
      • Account “Foreign exchange gain or loss, financing” → Financing category
    • Approach 2:
      • Account “Foreign exchange gain or loss” + Functional area “Investing” → Investing category
      • Account “Foreign exchange gain or loss” + Functional area “Financing” → Financing category
  • Consolidated financial statement:
    • Approach 1: Accounts “Foreign exchange gain or loss, investing”/“Foreign exchange gain or loss, financing” + Financial transaction type “IC loan, FX valn.” → Operating category
    • Approach 2: Account “Foreign exchange gain or loss” + Functional areas “Investing”/“Financing” + Financial transaction type “IC loan, FX valn.” → Operating category

Derivation of the financial transaction type “IC Loan, FX Valn.” can be configured via the app Additional Account Assignment (Substitution Rules)—by creating substitution rule(s) to derive this financing transaction type, based on relevant pre-conditions (e.g., product type of intercompany loan, update types for foreign currency valuation, valuation area 002 for IFRS, AAR representing the affiliated relationship with the counterparty).

For further details, refer to SAP help documentation: Additional Account Assignments - Substitution Rules.

Configuration counterpart mapping: Public Cloud vs. Private Cloud

entry.title: Unlocking the NPP: PayID
entry.content:
Welcome to the third installment of the Blog series on the New Payments Platform (“NPP”) in Australia.

The series is planned as:

  1. Unlocking the NPP: SAP Capabilities for Faster, Smarter Payments
  2. Unlocking the NPP: Payments overview
  3. Unlocking the NPP: PayID
  4. Unlocking the NPP: PayTo

 

PayID (OSKO)

PayID can be used as an alternative to specifying a Payee’s Bank Account and BSB details in an online Payment transaction or file. The PayID is chosen by the Payee and can be a mobile number, email address, ABN, or Organisation Identifier. PayID is also referred to as Osko, particularly in the context of Personal Banking.

The initial creation of the PayID is managed directly by the Payee with their Bank, typically through their online banking portal. The Bank will advise their customer (the Payee) which PayID types are available and will validate that the chosen PayID is not already in use, as well as checking it is in the required format. The central registry of PayIDs is part of the NPP infrastructure delivered by Australian Payments Plus (APP), with Banks able to query and update details. Once a PayID is created, the owner can change Banks and just update their existing PayID. 

The main benefits of using PayID in SAP are:

  • You don’t need to request or store Bank Account or BSB details in SAP, which could be regarded as sensitive information similar to Credit Card numbers. Individuals may be reluctant to divulge these as use of PayID / OSKO gains wider usage and security concerns increase.
  • The Payer no longer needs to update Payee Bank details in SAP if the Payee moves Banks or changes Bank Account details.

It is possible for a Payee to have more than one PayID and we’ll describe how this can be handled below.

 

PayID in pain.001 format

APP has produced the document For guidance on using NPP payment initiation messages which contains details on the expected mapping of the PayID (or “Proxy”) fields in the pain.001 file. The document refers to version 011 and describes these fields for PayID for outgoing payments:

  • Type - /CstmrCdtTrfInitn/PmtInf/CdtTrfTxI nf/CdtrAcct/Prxy/Tp/Prtry
  • Value - /CstmrCdtTrfInitn/PmtInf/CdtTrfTxI nf/CdtrAcct/Prxy/Id

You should be aware that these Proxy fields were only added to the ISO20021 pain.001 format in version 009. As described in the previous Blog, SAP standard content refers to version 006 so does not contain these Proxy fields. Similarly where Banks use version 003, these latest standard Proxy fields will not be available and they may direct usage of alternate fields. This can be managed through the standard DMEE configuration activities.

 

PayID in SAP

There are a couple of options for the management of PayID depending on your SAP system:

  • Bank Account Alias
    • Standard function for handling Account Proxy / PayID
    • Available for On Premise / Private Cloud from S/4HANA 2021 FPS01
    • Available in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Standard or Custom fields on Business Partner
    • For example if the Supplier uses a Phone number as their PayID, you could use standard fields from the Business Partner Communication data such as Telephone, Telex or Fax. However where these are already populated with different values, it may be necessary to use other fields or create your own.
    • Ensure you are familiar with the mapping process from Business Partner to standard Payment Structures (FPAYP, FPAYH and FPAYH). Leveraging the standard mapping will make it possible to define the source for PayID within the Payment Format without requiring additional coding.

Source of Information for Field in structures FPAYH-FPAYHX-FPAYP

  • Where coding is required, BAdI FBL_EVENT_06 enables population of ZREF01-ZREF10 fields which can then be mapped to the DMEE fields.

 

Bank Account Alias

We’ll take a look at the configuration and master data settings required to work with the Bank Account Alias using standard SAP functionality.

SSCUI for Public Cloud

IMG for On Premise and Private Cloud

 

Alias Types

  • Alias Type can be created to align to the standard NPP values or any Bank Specific values.
  • Validation determines how the field contents will be checked:
    • Tax number categories references the settings in
      • SSCUI 102415 - Maintain Tax Number Categories
      • SPRO Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Business Partner → Basic Settings → Tax Numbers → Define Tax Number Categories
      • Rule AU0 checks “VAT Reg.No. must have the length 11 or 14”
    • Email, Phone number and Organisation use Regular Expressions (code) to validate the length and format of the entries.
    • The NPP mapping guidance document (link above) includes sample RegEx code which can be pasted into each Validation Rule but you can easily create your own using SAP Joule for Consultants or other GenAI tools. Note that the NPP will accept any phone number but you may wish to limit to AU formats for landlines and mobiles (as shown in the above example).

 

Payment System configuration links the Alias Types to the Country.

 

The Bank Account Alias also needs a dedicated “Internal Bank” - a single entry is sufficient for country AU.

Manage Banks - Master Data F6437

 

Business Partner

The Bank Account Alias is maintained under Payment Transactions along with Bank Accounts. The above example shows the Alias is maintained with default ID “0001” which is fine if there is only one entry in the table. We'll see below how to handle BSB / Bank Account and / or additional PaYID for a Business Partner. 

 

The Bank Account Alias details are automatically mapped to the below fields in FFPAYH and from there can be mapped in DMEEX to the required pain.001 nodes.

 

PayID Validation

Whilst PayID has potential benefits, one of the issues to consider is how to ensure the PayID details entered on the Business Partner are correct. The Validation configuration settings will check the format, but will not ensure the actual value is correct and errors are possible. The PayID will be validated for existence by the Bank prior to forwarding the payment file to the NPP, however Customers will be responsible for ensuring the details are correct.

If you process a payment with a PayID through an Online Banking portal, you can view additional details on who the PayID is registered to. This provides additional confidence the payment will reach the desired Payee. This manual check could be used for low volume usage of PayID.

Unfortunately at this stage NPP does not provide the capability to perform automated checks as part of Master Data maintenance or prior to sending the Payment File to SAP or other Digital Service Providers.  The NPP “Confirmation of Payee” service only relates to payments made with BSB and Bank Account.

SAP Customers are recommended to discuss potential solutions with their Banks or to ensure Payees have verified the captured PayID information prior to using in Payment Files.

 

Working with PayID

Business Partner with Bank details and two PayIDs. The field "ID" on the BP Bank Details view is the same as the Partner Bank Type field on an Invoice Document header. The ID values will default to 0001, 0002 etc but can be populated with specific values such as PAY1, PAY2 etc at time of initial creation.

The system will follow the standard sequence for determination of Bank details in the payment run:

  1. Partner Bank Type (ID) in the Invoice document, either from manual entry or substitution. In S/4HANA Public Cloud this could be configuration or BADI.
  2. Partner Bank Type (ID) BTE 1810 (Private Cloud and On Premise only)
  3. Partner Bank Type (ID) with lowest ranking from Blank, then 0001 to ZZZZ. In the above example the Bank Key / Account would continue to be used as the default value of 0001 would be selected first.

Refer KBA 2983466 - Incorrect Partner Bank Type (BVTYP) is selected by Automatic Payment Program for further details.

 

You may also consider whether to create a new Payment Method for PayID payments as the configuration allows setting Bank Account Alias as mandatory on Business Partner. It also provides an easy way to separate Payment Runs.

SAP Help – Bank Account Alias

SAP Help – Business Partner – Bank Account Alias

 

PayID for incoming payments

The process of setting up a PayID for incoming payments is managed directly with the Bank. You may create a custom field on the Bank Account master data which can be included on outgoing invoices instead of the BSB and Bank Account details or just manage through Standard Texts. Your customers pay using the PayID but otherwise the Bank Statements and reconciliation process remain unchanged.

entry.title: SAP S4HANA Fiori Launchpad authentication via IAS (SAP Cloud Identity services)
entry.content:
Hello,

This blog will help us configure our S4HANA Fiori through SAP Cloud Identity Services and still using our own corporate IDP.

This is one of prerequisite of enabling joule for S4HANA Fiori launchpad for private cloud edition.

Our organization is already having SAML authentication for our Fiori users with our corporate IDP but in order to use Joule within Fiori SAP Fiori should also use same authentication method as that of Joule.

 Architectural flow 

Steps to integrate Fiori with IAS

  1. Get the SAML Metadata of Your Identity Authentication Tenant
  2. Create an App for Your SAP S/4HANA Solution
  3. Enable the ABAP Platform as an SAML Service Provider
  4. Trust Identity Authentication as an Identity Provider
  5. Trust the ABAP Platform Client as a Service Provider
  6. Configure Corporate IDP in SAP IAS
  7. Configuring the Conditional authentication for your app in IAS

Get the SAML Metadata of Your Identity Authentication Tenant

Login to your IAS tenant --> https://<tenant ID>.accounts.ondemand.com/admin

Under Applications & Resources, choose the Tenant Settings tile.

 

Choose the SAML 2.0 Configuration list item.

Choose Download Metadata File.

From the Signing Certificate section, download the certificate too.

 

Create an App for Your SAP S/4HANA Solution

Under Applications & Resources, choose the Applications tile.

Choose the Create button.

Enter the required information.

 

Set the Application Type to SAP on-premise Solution.

Click on create.

 

Enable the ABAP Platform as an SAML Service Provider

Login to your S4HANA system and open SAML 2.0 Configuration (transaction SAML2).

If your ABAP client has never been configured for SAML, you see the message Client "<Client_Id>" is not configured to support SAML 2.0.

To enable the configuration, choose Enable SAML 2.0 Support -->  Create SAML 2.0 Local Provider.

 
 
Enter a name for the provider.
 

 

 

 
Choose Metadata.

Save the metadata to a file, such as abap_client_metadata.xml.

Trust Identity Authentication as an Identity Provider

In SAML2 tcode goto Trusted Provider and click on add

Select the metadata file you downloaded from your Identity Authentication tenant for upload and choose Next.

Then you need to choose the certificate which you have downloaded from tenant setting

once you finish the wizard. provider is added as shown below

click on identity federation and click add

you can save and activate this provider

 

Trust the ABAP Platform Client as a Service Provider

login to SAP IAS https://<tenant ID>.accounts.ondemand.com/admin

Under Applications & Resources, choose the Applications tile.

Select the application you created for your ABAP Platform client

Under the Trust tab, choose SAML 2.0 Configuration.

 

Upload the service provider metadata XML file which you downloaded from SAML2 tcode

 

Configure Corporate IDP in SAP IAS

prerequisite : you need metadata file from your corporate IDP 

Login to IAS and go to Identity provided --> Corporate Identity Providers

click on SAML configuration

 

 

Name ID format you can keep unspecified

Configuring the Conditional authentication for your app in IAS

login to IAS and click on application and resource 

select your application " SAP ABAP " in my case

then scroll down to conditional authentication

choose the corporate IDP which you create in above step and click on save

you have to trust your corporate IDP 

you are all set

now when request comes from SAP Fiori it will be redirected to SAP IAS and SAP IAS will redirect that request to your corporate IDP. It will pass the authentication and same will be pass on to your SAP application by SAP IAS. It will just act like proxy.

In case if you are not using Corporate IDP for login then you need to create each SAP user in your SAP IAS so that they can login fiori with your SAP IAS login credentails.

 

Reference Article : https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity/system-integration-guide/identity-authentication-configuration-for-sap-s-4hana?locale=en-US

entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management – Part 4 (New Feature)
entry.content:
Multi-Company Integration: Scaling Across LoBs and Source Systems

In this blog part, I’ll dive into a major breakthrough released in December 2025: the ability to support N:N integration scenarios in Multiple Company integration scenario between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Field Management.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

Part 4 - Multi-Company Integration: Scaling Across LoBs and Source Systems

Previously, integrating master data from multiple source systems or Line of Businesses (LoBs) or Regions into multiple SAP FSM companies was a technical bottleneck. The standard integration content relied on a single Multiple Company Value Mapping artifact to manage company determination. This meant you couldn't easily maintain distinct mapping rules for different regions, or LoBs, or S/4HANA systems within a single SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) tenant.

This limitation is now a thing of the past.

Enabling N:N Integration via Value Mapping Prefixes

The latest update introduces a flexible strategy to support multiple S/4HANA sources or LoBs, each requiring its own unique multi-company mapping criteria. By using a Value Mapping Prefix, you can now deploy distinct mapping rules side-by-side in the same environment.

How it Works

  • Unique Identifiers: You can now assign a unique prefix (e.g., LOB1_ or REGION_A_) to your multiple company Value Mapping artifacts.
  • Independent Artifacts: Instead of one giant mapping table, the system creates separate, dedicated artifacts (e.g., LOB1_AccountCompany) for each specific source or business unit.
  • End-to-End Consistency: By configuring this prefix across all relevant integration flows, you ensure that data from Source A always follows Rule A, and Source B always follows Rule B.

Configuration Steps: How to Set It Up

To enable this, a new external parameter, ValueMappingPrefix, has been added to the standard suite of interfaces.

  1. Update Your Interfaces

You must configure the prefix value in the following standard iFlows to ensure they recognize the specific mapping rules for that LoB:

  • Synchronize Multiple Company Mapping Configuration
  • Replicate Business Partner (and Contacts/Relationships)
  • Replicate Products, Product Stock, and Product Price
  • Replicate Item Groups
  • Replicate Service Orders (SOAP)
  1. Practical Example

If you are setting up integration for "Line of Business 1":

  • Configure the Synchronize Multiple Company Mapping iFlow with the prefix LOB1_.
  • Deploy the iFlow. This automatically generates a new artifact named: LOB1_Value Mapping for Multiple Company determination in SAP FSM from SAP S4HANA.
  • Now, all data tagged with LOB1_ will use these specific rules, keeping your global configuration clean and organized.

  • Once your multi-company configuration has been synchronized to SAP Cloud Integration, you are ready to configure and deploy the master data iFlows. Ensure you specify the correct ValueMappingPrefix in each interface to route data accurately from S/4HANA to FSM, as shown in the example below:

Best Practices for Implementation

Pro Tip: To keep your integration landscape manageable, copy the standard package (“SAP S/4HANA Integration with SAP Field Service Management”) for each distinct LoB.

For each copied package:

  • Assign the unique prefix consistently across all iFlows within that package.
  • Synchronize sequentially: Update your mapping configuration in S/4HANA for one LoB at a time, then deploy the corresponding synchronization iFlow to push those rules to CPI.

Summary of Benefits

  • Scalability: Manage multiple S/4HANA systems in a single CPI tenant without data collisions.
  • Flexibility: Define region-specific or business-unit-specific rules for how data maps to FSM companies.
  • Reduced Complexity: No need for multiple CPI tenants to handle different business segments.

 

Note: This is an advanced configuration intended specifically for N:N integration scenarios (multiple source systems to multiple FSM companies) within a single SAP Cloud Integration tenant. By default, the ValueMappingPrefix is blank, supporting the standard 1:N integration (single S/4HANA source to multiple FSM companies).

entry.title: Canada T4A-NR 2025 Regulatory Changes: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance(DRC)
entry.content:
Towards the end of 2025, the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) rolled out updates to the T4A-NR slip, summary forms, and the T619 XML schema. These changes, which will affect filings due on or before the last day of February 2026, have been seamlessly integrated into SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solutions, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition /On-Premise. Here’s a detailed look at what these updates entail and how SAP is ensuring compliance.

Key Regulatory Changes

  1. Updated CRA Forms: The CRA has released new 2025 versions of the T4A-NR slip and the T4A-NR Summary (T4A-NR-SUM) for the 2025 tax year. While the content changes are minimal, using the correct form version is essential to avoid filing issues.
  2. T619 XML Schema Updates:
    • Mandatory Language Code: To ensure consistent language identification for CRA communications, the T619 electronic transmittal now requires a language code to specify English or French, denoted by “E” or “F” for every submission. Previously optional, this field is now mandatory for 2025 filings.
    • No Empty Fields in XML: A new validation rule mandates that any optional XML element with no data must be omitted entirely. This means if a data field doesn’t apply or is blank, the system should not generate that XML tag at all, as including empty tags can lead to file rejection by the CRA. 

SAP's Support of Regulatory Changes

As part ofSAP’s end-to-end compliance vision, the SAP Globalization Product Management team has proactively delivered the necessary updates to accommodate these CRA changes, to ensure that customers can generate compliant T4A-NR slips, summaries, and XML files across SAP Cloud ERP solutions:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: The T4A-NR form and summary Adobe print forms have been updated in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to match the CRA’s 2025 PDF layout. Electronic filing content for T4A-NR has been enhanced to output XML according to the new schema, delivered via the regular quarterly release.
  •  SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition/On-Premise: SAP Note 3691523 – “Canada T4A-NR Withholding Tax Reporting: Legal Changes 2025” was released, along with a support package containing the updated forms and electronic report definitions. Applying this note or support pack will ensure the system produces the correct 2025 forms and XML.

Next Steps 

  • Review and Implement SAP Update: Ensure your SAP S/4HANA system has the 2025 year-end legal change for T4A-NR applied. For SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, apply SAP Note 3691523. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud, confirm you’re on the latest release that includes the T4A-NR changes. Implement these updates before year-end processing.
  • Test Your Reporting: Generate a sample T4A-NR slip, summary, and XML file in a test environment. Verify that the slip and summary display “2025” and the latest form text. Ensure the language element is present and correctly set, and confirm that there are no empty tags in the file.
  • Consult CRA Resources: Refer to the CRA’s official XML specifications page for the updated schema download and guidance for 2025/2026 filings. The CRA’s T4A-NR guide (RC4445) for 2025, updated December 2025, is also a helpful reference. Links to the schema files and CRA documentation are available on the CRA website.

Call to Action

SAP customers and partners can avoid last-minute scrambles and ensure a smooth tax filing season by taking the following actions:

  • Review our published "What's New" SAP Help Portal documentation, apply, and test the delivered SAP changes promptly.
  • Engage your IT or SAP support team to confirm that your system is outputting the new form and schema correctly. Leverage the Regulatory Change Manager for agility in adapting to new legal requirements.
  • Visit the CRA’s XML specification page for the official schema and test your files against it. With proper preparation, you’ll be ready to file your 2025 T4A‑NR returns without issues.
  • Connect with us via the SAP support channels or Canada Localization Workzone if questions arise during this update process.
